title.value: Illuminating Protein Function Prediction Through Inter-Protein Similarity Modeling
title.justification: This is the title of the paper based on the provided content.
title.quote: Illuminating Protein Function Prediction Through Inter-Protein Similarity Modeling

extractions.description: The paper introduces a novel variational pseudo-likelihood framework, ProtIR, for protein function prediction. This framework iteratively refines predictors and retrievers to improve accuracy. The study benchmarks retriever-based methods against predictors on protein function tasks, demonstrating that retriever-based approaches can achieve comparable or superior performance without massive pre-training. Integrating structural information into protein language models further enhances function annotation capabilities.

type.justification: The paper presents experimental results on protein function prediction using various deep learning frameworks, making it an empirical study.
type.quote: To study the effect of inter-protein similarity modeling, in this paper, we comprehensively benchmark the retriever-based methods against predictors on protein function tasks, demonstrating the potency of retriever-based approaches.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on protein function prediction, which falls under the domain of Computational Biology.
name.quote: Proteins, central to biological systems, exhibit complex interactions between sequences, structures, and functions shaped by physics and evolution, posing a challenge for accurate function prediction.

name.justification: The paper deals with the analysis and interpretation of biological data, which is a core aspect of Bioinformatics.
name.quote: ... harnessing these extensive data, protein representation learning from sequences or structures has emerged as a promising approach for accurate function prediction.

name.justification: The paper employs machine learning techniques to improve protein function prediction.
name.quote: Recent advances in deep learning techniques demonstrate substantial potential for precise function prediction through learning representations from extensive protein sequences and structures.

name.justification: ProtIR is the novel framework introduced and proposed by the paper to enhance protein function prediction through iterative refinement between predictors and retrievers.
name.quote: Inspired by these findings, we first introduce an innovative variational pseudo-likelihood framework, ProtIR, designed to improve function prediction through iterative refinement between predictors and retrievers.

is_contributed.justification: ProtIR is a novel contribution proposed by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Inspired by these findings, we first introduce an innovative variational pseudo-likelihood framework, ProtIR, designed to improve function prediction through iterative refinement between predictors and retrievers.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed as part of the study to demonstrate its effectiveness.
is_executed.quote: Our experimental results on two state-of-the-art protein structure encoders, GearNet (Zhang et al., 2023a) and CDConv (Fan et al., 2023), clearly demonstrate that the ProtIR framework improves vanilla predictors by an average improvement of approximately 10% across different datasets.

is_compared.justification: ProtIR is extensively compared with other models in the paper.
is_compared.quote: The experimental results show that retriever-based methods can yield comparable or superior performance compared to predictor-based approaches without massive pre-training.

referenced_paper_title.justification: ProtIR is a novel contribution, so there is no reference paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Introduced a novel variational pseudo-likelihood framework, ProtIR, designed to improve function prediction through iterative refinement between predictors and retrievers.

name.justification: The SCOPe 1.75 database is mentioned as a key resource for pre-training protein structure encoders used within ProtIR.
name.quote: The encoder optimization involves maximizing the log likelihood: maxϕ log pϕ (cD |xD) = ∑_n∈D ∑[cn = c] log pϕ (cn = c|xn). Pre-training is done using 16,712 proteins from 1,195 different folds in the SCOPe 1.75 database.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The SCOPe 1.75 database is a well-known dataset in the field, commonly used for protein structure classification and does not have a single reference paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The encoder optimization involves maximizing the log likelihood: maxϕ log pϕ (cD |xD) = ∑_n∈D ∑[cn = c] log pϕ (cn = c|xn). Pre-training is done using 16,712 proteins from 1,195 different folds in the SCOPe 1.75 database.

name.justification: AlphaFold2 is used for structure prediction in the study and is referenced as a significant tool for this purpose.
name.quote: Recent advancements in structure retrievers (van Kempen et al., 2023), along with progress in structure prediction protocols (Jumper et al., 2021), have paved the way to explore function prediction methods based on various structure retrievers.

referenced_paper_title.value: Highly accurate protein structure prediction with AlphaFold
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the original paper describing the AlphaFold2 method.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Recent advancements in structure retrievers (van Kempen et al., 2023), along with progress in structure prediction protocols (Jumper et al., 2021), have paved the way to explore function prediction methods based on various structure retrievers.
